metadata.product: TIJN Blue Light Blocking Glasses Square Nerd Eyeglasses Frame

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: Hi Jacob, thank you so much for taking the time to chat with me today. My name is Jessica, and I'm with the product development team here at TIJN. We really appreciate you sharing your feedback with us through your review, and we're hoping to learn a bit more about your experience with our blue light blocking glasses. Is now still a good time for you?

transcript.speaker: Jacob
transcript.text: Yeah, absolutely, Jessica. Thanks for reaching out. Always happy to give feedback, especially for products I actually use.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: Great, thanks Jacob. So, just to start, could you tell me a little bit about what initially led you to look for blue light blocking glasses in the first place? Your review mentioned a lot of screen time, but what was the tipping point, so to speak?

transcript.speaker: Jacob
transcript.text: Right. Well, like I said in the review, my job as a UX designer pretty much means I'm glued to a screen. And it's not just one; it's a laptop, two big monitors at the office, and then my phone for everything else. I started noticing... gosh, probably about six months ago, just a constant, dull ache behind my eyes. And by the end of the day, my eyes would feel super dry, gritty, almost like I'd been staring into a fan all day. I called it a "screen hangover" because that's really what it felt like – just exhausted and hazy vision. I'd heard about blue light glasses, but honestly, I was skeptical.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: That "screen hangover" description is really vivid, thank you for that. So, once you decided to try them, what made you choose our TIJN square frames specifically, especially when there are so many options out there?

transcript.speaker: Jacob
transcript.text: Good question. I think it was a few things. First off, the look. I mean, they're called "nerd" eyeglasses, right? And I actually like that kind of slightly retro, understated look. They felt pretty stylish, and the photos looked good. But honestly, the biggest factor was probably the price. I figured, if this whole blue light thing was just a gimmick, or if they didn't really work for me, I wouldn't be out a lot of money. It was a really low-risk way to, you know, just test the waters without committing to something expensive.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: That makes perfect sense – a good entry point to see if the technology works for you. When they arrived, you mentioned the simple packaging, but when you actually picked up the glasses for the first time, what were your immediate thoughts on the quality and the feel?

transcript.speaker: Jacob
transcript.text: Hmm. Okay, so presentation-wise, like I said, nothing fancy. A soft pouch and a cloth, which is fine, totally functional. But when I actually took them out... I guess I was a little surprised by how light they felt. Almost *too* light, if that makes sense? They definitely look good, the matte finish is nice, and they have that modern aesthetic I liked. But just holding them, they felt a bit flimsy, you know? The plastic isn't exactly premium grade. I wasn't expecting, like, Italian acetate for the price, but there's just this nagging feeling that they might not stand up to daily handling for a long time. The hinges feel okay, though. Not super robust, but not loose either. They're... adequate.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: I understand. That perception of flimsiness, even if they haven't broken yet, can definitely impact the overall user experience. You also mentioned the yellow tint when you first put them on. Can you elaborate on how that affected your day-to-day use, especially with your work in UX design?

transcript.speaker: Jacob
transcript.text: Oh, the tint. Yeah, that was instant. It's not like I suddenly saw the world in sepia, but it's definitely there. Whites become a warmer off-white, and blues are toned down. For general stuff, like reading emails, browsing news sites, or even just working on documents with black text on white backgrounds, it was actually pretty nice. Made the screen feel softer, less harsh on my eyes. The problem, though, is my job. I'm constantly reviewing creative assets, designing landing pages, looking at color palettes. And for that, any color distortion is a non-starter. I found myself having to take them off multiple times a day.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: So, if you're reviewing a client's brand guidelines or checking the accuracy of a logo, you just can't wear them?

transcript.speaker: Jacob
transcript.text: Exactly. Or if I'm editing a photo, even just a personal one. If I'm trying to match a specific hex code or make sure a blue is the *right* blue, I just can't trust what I'm seeing through the glasses. It's a noticeable interruption to my workflow. I'll be in the zone, then remember, "Oh, wait, I can't do this with these on," and then I have to take them off, put them somewhere, do the task, and then put them back on. It breaks my concentration.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: That's a significant point, especially for a professional in your field. Thinking about comfort, you mentioned they were good for short periods but started to cause pressure after about four hours. Could you describe what that pressure felt like and where exactly it was most bothersome?

transcript.speaker: Jacob
transcript.text: Yeah, so for the first hour or two, they're super comfortable because, like I said, they're so light. You almost forget you're wearing them. But after, say, three to four hours, I'd start to feel a subtle pressure behind my ears from the thin arms. It wasn't excruciating, but it was just... there, a constant low-level annoyance. And the molded nose pads – I think because they're fixed, not adjustable – they'd start to irritate the bridge of my nose a bit. Not like a sore spot, but just a persistent feeling of something pressing down. And then, related to that, they'd tend to slide down my nose, especially if I was leaning forward, looking at my desk or whatever. So I'd have to push them back up, oh, I don't know, maybe five, six times an hour? It just adds to the little distractions.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: Those little adjustments can definitely add up over a long workday. Shifting to effectiveness, you mentioned a "slight reduction" in eye strain and headaches. On a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 being no change and 10 being a dramatic, life-altering improvement, how would you rate the reduction in your eye strain and screen-related headaches?

transcript.speaker: Jacob
transcript.text: Hmm, that's a good way to put it. For eye strain, I'd say... maybe a 5 or 6? It's not like my eyes feel perfectly refreshed, but they definitely don't feel as gritty or tired by 5 PM as they used to. There's a noticeable difference, just not a "wow, this is amazing" difference. And for headaches, probably a 4. They've lessened in *frequency*, for sure, but they haven't disappeared entirely. I still get them, especially if I've had a particularly intense screen day. So, a subtle, consistent improvement rather than a cure.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: And what about sleep? You mentioned you weren't expecting miracles, but did you observe any minor changes at all, positive or negative, in your sleep patterns or how quickly you fell asleep?

transcript.speaker: Jacob
transcript.text: Honestly, no. Not that I noticed, anyway. I wear them sometimes in the evening if I'm just scrolling on my phone or watching TV, but I haven't tracked my sleep or anything like that, so it's hard to say definitively. I tend to fall asleep pretty quickly anyway, so I didn't see any obvious changes there. It wasn't a primary motivation for buying them, though, so I wasn't particularly disappointed.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: That's fair. Now, considering everything we've discussed – the pros like the style and the subtle effectiveness, and the cons like the build quality concerns, the color distortion for your work, and the comfort issues for long wear – how do you feel about the price you paid for these glasses? Do you feel it was a good value?

transcript.speaker: Jacob
transcript.text: Given the price point... yeah, I think it's still a decent value for what it is. I mean, I paid under fifty bucks, right? For that, I got something that looks good, offers some blue light filtering, and gives me a mild reduction in eye strain. So, as an "entry-level" product, it served its purpose perfectly: it let me see if blue light blocking was even worth investing in. If I had paid, say, triple the amount, I'd be much more critical. But for what I shelled out, it's a solid 3-star option, like I said in the review. It's a good gateway product.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: "Gateway product," I like that term. It really puts it into perspective. If we were to develop a "premium" version of these glasses, what two or three things would be at the top of your list for improvement that would make you willing to pay more?

transcript.speaker: Jacob
transcript.text: Okay, definitely, number one would be **build quality**. I'd want something that feels more robust, more durable. Maybe a slightly heavier, higher-grade plastic, or even a different material. Something that feels like it could handle being tossed in a bag or dropped occasionally without me worrying it's going to snap. Number two, for sure, would be **color accuracy**. If you could achieve the blue light filtering without that noticeable yellow tint, or at least significantly reduce it, that would be a game-changer for someone in my line of work. I'd pay good money for that, honestly, because it would mean I could wear them all day, uninterrupted. And then maybe **comfort for extended wear**. Adjustable nose pads would be fantastic. And slightly wider, maybe softer, ear arms to prevent that pressure. Those three things would transform them from a "decent entry-level" to an "all-day professional" tool for me.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: Those are incredibly clear and actionable suggestions, Jacob, thank you. To wrap things up, based on your experience, how likely would you be to recommend these specific TIJN blue light blocking glasses to a friend or colleague, on a scale of 0 to 10, where 0 is "not at all likely" and 10 is "extremely likely"?

transcript.speaker: Jacob
transcript.text: Hmm. For me, personally, probably a 6. I'd tell them, "Look, if you're curious about blue light glasses and you don't want to spend a lot, these are a good starting point. They look good, and they *do* help a bit. Just be aware of the tint for color-sensitive work and the comfort for super long days." But I probably wouldn't recommend them to, say, another UX designer without a lot of caveats. If someone was just a casual user, mostly browsing or watching movies, maybe an 8. It really depends on who I'm talking to.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: That distinction is really helpful, Jacob. Your feedback has been incredibly valuable in understanding the nuances of your experience and where we can truly make an impact. We genuinely appreciate your honesty and time today.

transcript.speaker: Jacob
transcript.text: No problem, Jessica. Happy to help. It's good to know companies actually listen to reviews.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: We absolutely do. Thanks again, Jacob, and have a great rest of your day!

transcript.speaker: Jacob
transcript.text: You too. Bye.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: Bye.
